headline: Report: Mastriano Leads in New Gov Poll, Barletta Falls Behind
author: WKOK Staff
sentences: Christopher Nicholas, president of Eagle Consulting Group which is working on Gerow’s campaign, said, “this poll shows the millions that McSwain and his backers have spent on TV ads is starting to boost his stock in the primary.” However, he also noted the poll took place before Tuesday’s announcement by former President Donald Trump that he was not endorsing McSwain and had convinced Corman, who was ready to withdraw his candidacy, to stay in the race.

The remaining GOP candidates – state senator Jake Corman of Centre County; county commissioner Joe Gale of Montgomery County, political strategist Charlie Gerow of Cumberland County, attorney Melissa Hart of Allegheny County, and retired heart and lung surgeon Nche Zama of Northampton County – all receiving less than 2% support.

The poll’s findings that come on the heels of one by Emerson College Polling conducted the week before that also had Mastriano leading the pack with 16.2% of the 372 likely voters followed by Barletta at 12.4%, McSwain at 6.4%, and Dave White at 5.7%.

The poll shows Mastriano, a state senator from Franklin County, with 19% support from among the 502 likely GOP primary voters who were polled between April 7 and April 9 by Eagle Consulting Group, a Republican consulting firm based in Harrisburg.

HARRISBURG – PennLive is reporting… With a little more than a month to go before the May 17 primary, Republican gubernatorial candidate Doug Mastriano holds the lead in the crowded field of candidates vying for that party’s nomination.

Just as notable, it found 44% of those polled remain undecided as to who will get their vote in the primary to face off against presumed Democratic nominee Josh Shapiro, who is unopposed for his party’s nomination.

He was followed by former federal prosecutor Bill McSwain of Chester County with 12.75% support; former congressman Lou Barletta of Luzerne County with 11% and businessman Dave White of Delaware County, with 7%.
The Eagle Consulting Poll has a margin of error of plus or minus 4.38% and was conducted by an automated phone system for those with landlines and via text for those contacted by cell phone.
Emerson’s poll had a projected 5% margin of error.
